quotes: My portfolio compiles... most of the time.
Code is like a joke. If you have to explain it, it's probably bad.
I put the *fun* in *functional programming* (and the bug in debug).
This portfolio runs on coffee, chaos, and stack overflow tabs.
I don't always test my code, but when I do — it's in production.
My GitHub is basically a museum of unfinished greatness.
I'm not lazy — I'm just optimizing for minimal keystrokes.
Warning: May contain unhandled exceptions and bad puns.
Behind every great developer is a series of commit messages that say 'fix stuff'.
My code runs faster when I don't look at it.
I use dark mode because light attracts bugs.
Yes, this portfolio is responsive. Emotionally? Not so much.
I tried turning it off and on again — now I'm unemployed.
It's not a bug, it's an undocumented feature.
Some people have hobbies. I have recursive side projects.
My stack: HTML, CSS, JS, and pure existential dread.
I write code the same way I cook — without reading the documentation.
Warning: Portfolio may contain traces of spaghetti code.
Debugging: Being the detective in a crime movie where you are also the murderer.
I refactor my portfolio more than I update my resume.
Code so clean you could eat off it (if you ignore the commented-out disasters).
Real developers ship before they're ready. Legends never stop 'improving' their portfolio.
If it works on my machine, it's your problem now.
My portfolio isn't finished — it's *perpetually in alpha*.
Sometimes I write code that even I don't understand. Future me will hate this.
I named my portfolio 'final_final_v2_reallyfinal.md'.
Hello world. Again. And again. And again.
I measure productivity in commits per cup of coffee.
I keep my CSS and my emotions well-hidden.
This is my portfolio. I'll fix it in post-production.
This project runs on caffeine and hope.
I refactor, therefore I am.
Code is like a joke — if you have to explain it, it's bad.
I use dark mode because light attracts bugs.
Compiles on my machine. Deploy at your own risk.
My GitHub is 90% experiments and 10% accidents.
It's not a bug, it's an undocumented feature.
I refactor, therefore I am.
This project runs on caffeine and hope.
Behind every great developer is a commit message that says 'fix stuff'.
I don't always test my code, but when I do—it's in production.
My portfolio compiles... most of the time.
